origin of mantras
mantras originated with the great
ancient teachings of india called vedas
the rig veda the oldest and the most
central vedic text contains most of the
mantras according to david frawley the
great scholar in vedic literature the
rigveda is the fountainhead of vedic
science the ancient spiritual science of
the himalayas from which such system as
yoga vedic astrology jyotish and
ayurveda traditional indian medicine
arose it is the basis of the sanskrit
language and culture it is also the
oldest book in any indo-european
language there is a general recognition
that the mantric or sound power of the
vedic chants in the sansworth language
is the most sacred and mysterious power
that human language has ever achieved
according to the vedic tradition the
mantras have their origin in lord shiva

holinath that is lord shiva merrily
raised his dumroo or drum and began

rhythm millions of sounds spread in the
sky like stars in space every time the
string of the damaru swooshed through
the air it created a sound many other
sounds of different frequencies were
produced when the beads at the end of
the string would strike the damaru heads
shiva's moving hands and feet too
created sounds his swaying matted locks
the sound of rudraksha beads around his
wrist the slithering cobra around his
neck every movement gave birth to a
sound and each sound was a mantra
representing the feminine masculine or
neutral aspect of creation from this
kundalini or ear loops originated the
seed syllables of kundalini the sages of
your meditating on nirguna brahma the
formless were quick to perceive these
sounds
this is why shiva is regarded as the
only creator of mantras in mantra yoga

the philosophy of the mantras

mantra the power of repetition
a mantra is basically words every mantra
is a kind of cryptic code but sounds
like an ordinary sentence and if you
utter it like a sentence it carries no
power the mysterious power of mantra
occurs when it is repeated again and
again when it is chanted in a particular
way what does that really mean it means
that words when repeated carry
tremendous power the power of mantras is
not in their meaning but in their
repetitiveness
this idea is not specific to eastern
vedic tradition in fact you can see the

the rhythmic repetition sounds very much
like a mantra chanting
in buddhist traditions they use a prayer
wheel to repeat the names prayers in a
pattern
and it is the repetition the cycle of

lovelier
the name becomes sacred and powerful
